TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , a NORP national of NORP origin , was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . The applicant left GPE for GPE and GPE in DATE , with his mother . They arrived in GPE in DATE and lodged an asylum request there .

CARDINAL . He claimed in his asylum proceedings that in DATE his father had been shot before his eyes . The applicant ’s father had worked in the security services of former President PERSON , a separatist leader , which was why he and his family had been persecuted . Furthermore , the applicant had been arrested CARDINAL times and only released after the payment of a ransom . The applicant stated that he had been ill - treated during those arrests and also that in DATE NORP soldiers had brutally beaten him in the course of an identity check .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Bundesasylamt ) dismissed the applicant ’s asylum request as unfounded . It found the applicant ’s story contradictory and unconvincing and also found that he had failed to substantiate the existence of any real risk to himself .
CARDINAL . It seems that the applicant ’s mother ’s asylum request was also dismissed , for the same reasons .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant and his mother appealed . However , after an oral appeal hearing , the applicant withdrew his appeal on DATE due to allegedly wrong legal advice he received at the time .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG ( Asylgerichtshof ) allowed the applicant ’s mother ’s appeal and granted her the status of a recognised refugee . As regards her flight story it found as follows :
“ The following has been established concerning the appellant and her reasons for fleeing :
The appellant claims to be a GPE national of NORP ethnic origin and , prior to fleeing , lived in the village of GPE in GPE .

It is credible that in the event of her return to her country of origin , the appellant would be under threat from ORG authorities or third parties on account of her membership of a particular social group . The appellant alleged that she was under threat from NORP and NORP security forces because of her husband ’s previous activities .
It has been found plausible that the appellant ’s husband was an officer for a NORP security agency and was murdered by the security forces on DATE in the village of GPE .

The findings as to the appellant and her reasons for fleeing result from the descriptions given by the persons examined at the hearing , which – in this respect – are consistent and credible . The appellant was able to give a description of her husband ’s murder that was clear and consistent with her previous statements , thereby conveying the impression of having actually experienced what she was talking about . The witness ORG gave a convincing statement confirming that the appellant ’s husband worked for a NORP security agency . ”
CARDINAL . After referring to a number of general country reports on GPE and the north GPE region , ORG continued its legal assessment of the facts of the applicant ’s mother ’s case , as follows :

“ Regard being had to the findings concerning the situation of NORP in GPE , the appellant faces an objective risk of persecution in view of the facts established as to her reasons for seeking asylum . The appellant ’s husband was murdered in his homeland because of his work for a NORP security agency . Accordingly , the appellant is already known to the NORP and pro - NORP authorities and has come specifically to their attention . This means that she is in particular danger of being arrested by the security forces in GPE , and in such an eventuality there is a significant probability that she would be at risk of suffering human rights violations . Moreover , in view of the situation in GPE and the fact that the appellant is known by name to the authorities , it can not be assumed with sufficient certainty that she would not be exposed in other parts of GPE , for example , to attacks of any kind warranting asylum or that she could expect effective protection from the authorities against such attacks . Accordingly , the appellant – who , moreover , is suffering from post - traumatic stress disorder – has no reasonable internal flight alternatives available either . ”

CARDINAL . An appeal by the applicant against this decision was granted suspensive effect . In his appeal the applicant claimed deficiencies of the proceedings and a wrong legal assessment of the established facts by ORG . He claimed that , because he was still at real risk of persecution if he returned to GPE and because of the deterioration of the security situation there , his subsequent asylum request could not be considered a res judicata .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal as unfounded . In the summary of the facts of the case , it referred to the applicant ’s mother , wife and children , while again citing the file numbers of their asylum proceedings .

CARDINAL . As regards the nature of a res judicata , it reiterated that a new decision on the merits of an application could only be based upon a change of circumstances which was significant enough to allow the conclusion , either alone or in combination with other facts , that those reasons for which the former application had been dismissed were to be evaluated differently in the present proceedings . Referring to long - standing administrative jurisprudence , it further stated that the credibility of the alleged new facts had to be evaluated anew in the context of all former investigation results in the event that those alleged new facts could prima facie lead to a different outcome of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . ORG went on and established that the applicant ’s reasons for leaving GPE presented in the subsequent proceedings had already been deemed unconvincing by the previous final decision . It therefore confirmed that the applicant had not presented any relevant new information with regard to his asylum request . Furthermore , the applicant was not suffering from any severe psychological or physical illness , and still had friends and family living in GPE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of General Administrative Procedure ( Allgemeines Verwaltungsverfahrensgesetz ) provided that submissions from individuals who request modification of a ruling which is not , or is no longer , subject to appeal , shall be rejected as res judicata . In this context the DATE LAW ( DATE ) included in its section QUANTITY § CARDINAL a reference to section CARDINAL of LAW that
“ Decisions rejecting or dismissing a request under the [ former versions of the ] Asylum Act ... shall constitute res judicata in proceedings under LAW concerning the same facts . ”
CARDINAL . ORG has observed in its jurisprudence as follows ( see judgment of ORG of DATE , no . CARDINAL ) :

“ An alleged change in circumstances may entitle and require the authority to give a fresh decision on the merits – once it has carried out any necessary investigations of its own motion under LAW of LAW – only where such a change , by itself or in combination with other facts , would be of legal relevance to the question of asylum ; a different legal assessment of the request must not be prima facie inconceivable . Furthermore , the alleged change in circumstances must have at least a credible basis which is relevant to the question of asylum and to which to the above - mentioned prospect of a positive decision can be linked . To that end , as soon as it begins to examine the admissibility of the ( fresh ) asylum request , the authority must address the credibility of the asylum - seeker ’s allegations and , where appropriate , the evidential value of any certificates . Should the authority ’s investigations conclude that , contrary to the party ’s allegations , a change in circumstances which is prima facie capable of giving rise to a different assessment has not in fact occurred , the asylum request must be rejected in accordance with section CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see decision of DATE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL , with further references ; see also the case - law recapitulated in PERSON , Verwaltungsverfahrensgesetze I , CARDINALnd ed . , notes CARDINAL et seq . on section CARDINAL of LAW ) . ”

CARDINAL . This section gives a short overview of selected reports from various easily accessible sources on the security and human rights situation in GPE available at the time of the applicant ’s subsequent asylum proceedings in GPE .
CARDINAL . The Commissioner stated that the north GPE has been a region of major interest and concern from the very beginnings of the office of the Commissioner of Human Rights in DATE .

CARDINAL . The Commissioner noted that the lifting of the DATE - long counterterrorist operation in GPE had not been accompanied by a diminution in the activities of illegal armed groups . Federal and NORP authorities had carried out CARDINAL special operations in DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL ) . The report further noted an increase in the number of abductions and disappearances in GPE since DATE . In some cases , the involvement of law - enforcement officials had been alleged ( see paragraph CARDINAL ) . Finally , the lack of effective investigations of repeated human rights violations , the alleged involvement of law - enforcement officials in crimes , and the deficiencies of the judiciary , were concerns which had been raised by both the current Commissioner and his predecessor ( see paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . He concluded the report with regret , in view of the fact that stability in the north GPE region had yet to be achieved . Increased activity by illegal armed groups , the lack of effective investigations of disappearances and killings , and murders of human rights activists were of particular concern . Patterns of impunity persisted , even though there were indications of serious efforts to reinforce the rule of law . The difficult economic situation was one of the destabilising factors , and the need for economic development and further social reconstruction was evident ( see paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . This report described the north GPE region of GPE as remaining an area of particular concern . The government ’s poor human rights record in the north GPE worsened as the government fought insurgents , NORP militants , and criminal forces . Local government and insurgent forces reportedly engaged in killing , torture , abuse , violence , politically motivated abductions , and other brutal or humiliating treatment , often with impunity . In GPE , PERSON and ORG , the number of extrajudicial killings and disappearances increased markedly , as did the number of attacks on law - enforcement personnel . Authorities in the north GPE appeared to be acting outside federal government control . Although the NORP government announced a formal end to counterterrorist operations , there was an increase in violence during DATE , which continued through the remainder of DATE . Federal and local security forces in GPE , as well as the private militia of NORP president PERSON , allegedly targeted families of suspected insurgents for reprisals and committed other abuses . There were also reports of rebel involvement in bombing civilian targets and of politically motivated disappearances in the region . Some rebels were allegedly involved in kidnapping for ransom . According to the PERSON news agency ORG , CARDINAL members of law - enforcement agencies lost their lives and CARDINAL were injured during DATE in actions involving insurgents . CARDINAL of internally displaced persons were living in temporary centres in the region : the centres failed to meet international standards .

CARDINAL . Under the heading “ Use of Excessive Force and Other Abuses in Internal Conflicts ” , it was noted that during DATE complex and inter - connected insurgencies caused continuing instability in the north GPE , with a marked upsurge in incidents committed by government and insurgent forces during DATE . Overall , there were increases in disappearances , killings , and other abuses . There were reports that federal and local security forces seeking to quell the insurgencies were continuing to use excessive force and to engage in human rights abuses , including torture , summary executions , disappearances , and arbitrary detentions . Authorities in the north GPE were reportedly acting with impunity , and some observers alleged that the federal government had ceded de facto control of the region to local authorities . Rebels were also continuing to commit human rights abuses , including major acts of terrorism and summary executions .
